title: Online onsite admission test Radio Navigation v23.2

questions.query:
When the modulation depth (M) is 100%…

  1. The amplitude of the modulation signal is the same as the amplitude of the carrier wave.
  2. The carrier wave is fully suppressed and can no longer be received.

options.text: Only statement 1 is true; statement 2 is false.
Only statement 1 is false; statement 2 is true.

questions.query: When the depth of modulation (M) is 0%...

options.text: the aircraft is on the localiser and on the glide-slope of the ILS.
the amplitude of the modulating signal equals the amplitude of the carrier wave.
the ratio between the amplitude of the modulating signal and the amplitude of the carrier wave is zero.
the difference between the frequency of the carrier wave and the frequency of the modulating signal is zero.

questions.query: When a radio signal changes its propagation direction due to a different medium the radio waves are travelling through, this is called...
A radio wave is a(n)...
A vertical antenna has...

options.comment:
two "nulls" and one "lobe".

A lobe is always in a 3D plane.

questions.query: The polarisation of a vertical antenna is...
Why does a flat-plate, phased-array antenna result in a larger range than a parabolic-dish antenna?

options.text: A flat plate antenna can transmit more power.
A flat plate antenna has less side lobes.
A flat plate antenna has a lower pulse repetition frequency (PRF).
A flat plate antenna is not moving.

questions.query: What would be the length of a monopole antenna which is suited for 1000 MHz?

Which formula correctly shows the maximum theoretical range (MTR) of VHF radio waves?

 

Note:
All ranges in NM and all heights in feet.
At periods of super refraction...

options.text: sky waves are refracted by clouds of free electrons causing an increasing skip distance.
ground waves can reach further when the transmission power is increased.
direct waves are curved towards the earth surface, resulting in a decreasing the ground range.
space waves are curved towards the earth surface, resulting in an increased ground range.

questions.query:
Which of the following statements regarding propagation of radio waves is true?

  1. The groundwave has its lowest range in the VLF-LF band.
  2. The sky wave is primarily used in the MF-HF band.
  3. The surface wave occurs in the VHF-UHF band.
  4. The space wave is the only wave that occurs in the SHF-EHF band.

Bonus question!

Als je deze goed hebt, mag je een andere fout beantwoorde vraag terugtrekken!

 

A radio transmitter has a frequency of 2 MHz and the transmitting power for a range of 1000 wavelengths.

If during a transmission in the night the F-layer (no E and D layers) is at an altitude of 300 km, and the critical angle of incidence is 21º, the distance of the skip zone is approximately...

options.comment:
tan 21 = half skip distance / 300 -> skip distance is 230 km.

At 2 MHz, 1 wave length = 3x108 / 2x106 = 150 m -> 1000 wave lengths is 150 km.

Skip zone is 230 - 150 = 80 km.

questions.query: VDF responds to the...
The indicator of the ground VDF equipment responds to the...

options.text: voice modulated signal transmitted by the aircraft.

questions.query: In which of the following circumstances will VDF most likely be used to determine the position of an aircraft.

options.text: If an aircraft transmits an urgency (pan-pan) call on any frequency.
If ATC is contacted in order to fly from an uncontrolled airspace to a controlled airspace.
When the pilot transmits a distress call (Mayday) on 121.5 MHz.
At first contact after passing the FIR boundary.

questions.query: Which of the following statements about ADF and/or NDB is correct?

options.text: The BFO is a component of the ADF.
The only purpose of the vertical sense antenna is to enable the ADF to receive the ident.
The quadrantal error is caused by disturbances in the propagation path crossing the coast.
The frequency band is limited to 190 - 450 kHz.

questions.query: The quadrantal error of an ADF receiver is caused by...
What is the minimum number of NDB's to take a QTF?
One, single loop antenna can be found at...

options.comment: VDF makes use of several loop antennas aranged as an Adcock antenna.

questions.query: The accuracy of an NDB bearing is affected by...

options.text: precipitation static, mountain effect and turning error.
radio noise, Doppler effect and deviation error.
heavy snow and rain, coastal effect and dip error.

questions.query: The reception of a VOT will result in an RMI indication, that is...

options.text: dependent of the position of the aircraft.
options.comment: No, the reception of a VOT will always result in an indication of radial 360.

questions.query: Which statement is true for a VOR?

options.text: VOR's have monitoring stations at the boundary of their designated operational coverage.
The accuracy of a TVOR is better than that of an airway VOR.
The transmission power of a VOT and an TVOR is the same.

questions.query: The frequency band for VOR is...
The 'site errors' around a VOR are...

options.text: smaller for a DVOR than for a CVOR due to the antenna system.
negligible at a TVOR due to the smaller range.
not present at a CVOR due to the 'counterpoise'.
are very small due to the application of vertical polarised antennas.

questions.query: Which two-statement answer regarding VOR is true?

options.text: The capacity of the system is unlimited, and there is no ambiguity.
The line-of-position is a radial, and the accuracy of a CVOR and a DVOR are equal.
A full-scale-deflection is five degrees, and the transmission power is the same for all kinds of VOR stations.
The range is line-of-sight, and the transmission frequency is in the UHF-band.

questions.query: System- or beacon saturation of the DME system...

options.text: occurs when more than 90 aircraft are demanding replies from one single ground station.
occurs when the flight crew forgets to select the DME from the 'search mode' to the 'standby mode'.
can be avoided by increasing the station delay time from 50 to150 microseconds.
is solved by introducing X- and Y-channels, resulting in 252 available interrogation frequencies.

questions.query: The capacity of a DME ground station is determined by the amount of...

options.text: aircraft that fly within the range of the DME ground station.
interrogators in the search-mode in relation to the amount of interrogators in the tracking-mode.

questions.query: The DME velocity memory is used to...

options.text: calculate the groundspeed from the sensed lateral acceleration.
store and show the mean ground speed of the last 15 seconds.
calculate the groundspeed from the change in DME distance even when the signal has disappeared for max 15 seconds.
calculate the groundspeed with help of the Doppler frequency shift due to the velocity of the aircraft.

questions.query: The purpose of a DME velocity memory is...

options.text: to remain in the track mode, if the antenna is shielded for a period of maximum 15 seconds.
to compensate for the Doppler effect due to the relative groundspeed of the aircraft.

questions.query: Which statement about DME is true?

options.text: DME has X- and Y-channels in order to create the possibility to use the same DME frequency for two DME stations.
When a DME changes over from the 'tracking mode' to the 'memory mode', the interrogation frequency increases.
In case of an ILS/DME, the DME frequency has to be selected separately by the pilot.
The accuracy of a DME/N and a DME/P are equal.

questions.query:
On an ILS approach chart, there is a table that shows the required 'rate-of-descent' for a number of groundspeeds in order to fly a certain glidepath.

Under which conditions can the DME groundspeed read-out be used for this purpose?

  1. ILS/DME abeam the touch down zone;
  2. VOR/DME within 5 NM in front of the runway;
  3. TACAN within 5 NM from the airport;
  4. VORTAC 5 NM behind the runway.
Which statement is correct regarding ILS-indications?

options.text: The calibration of the course deviation indicator (CDI) depends on the position of the course pointer (CP).
Just before a normal glide-path (GP) intercept, the GP-pointer will have an upward deflection.
When passing the outer marker (OM), the white light will come on at a rate of 400 Hz.
At an ILS/DME the station delay is adapted in order to show the remaining distance to the end of the runway.

questions.query: When flying an ILS approach, the following modulation signals will be received...

options.text: 90 Hz and 150 Hz navigation components plus a 1020 Hz identification signal.
400 Hz and 1350 Hz navigation components plus 90 Hz and 150 Hz identification signals.
75 Hz and 150 Hz navigation signals plus 1020 Hz and 1350 Hz ident signals.
400 Hz, 1300 Hz and 3000 Hz navigation signals plus a 75 Hz ident signal.

questions.query: The transmission of the ILS glidepath beacon is characterised by a...

options.text: UHF frequency with a minimum range of 10 NM.
series of two 30 Hz signals of which the difference in depth of modulation is measured.
VHF frequency modulated carrier wave with a 90 Hz AM and a 150 Hz AM navigation signal.

questions.query: Whn flying a 3° glide path with a groundspeed of 100 kt, the rate-of-descent is...
Beam bends are...

options.text: slight curves in the ILS radio signals that can be followed by large aircraft.
curves in the GP signal that are visible on the indicator, but change too fast to be followed by a large aircraft.
curves that are part of the normal LOC approach procedure because of 'noise abatement'.
curved approaches that are made with the aid of the microwave landing system.

questions.query:
Given an ILS-DME approach.

Three-dimensional guidance to the runway-threshold can be expected from a distance of...
Regarding ILS, when the DDM is zero...
The MLS datablocks are transmitted as...

options.comment:
Correct.

Several datablocks behind each other preceeded by a pre-amble.

questions.query: Which statement about MLS radio beams is true?

options.text:
azimuth beam: narrow in azimuth and wide in elevation;

elevation beam: narrow in elevation and wide in azimuth.

azimuth beam: wide in azimuth and narrow in elevation;

elevation beam: wide in elevation and narrow in azimuth.

azimuth beam: wide in azimuth and narrow in elevation;

elevation beam: narrow in elevation and narrow in azimuth.

azimuth beam: narrow in azimuth and narrow in elevation;

elevation beam: wide in elevation and narrow in azimuth.

questions.query: Compared to ILS, MLS has the advantage of...

options.text: far less sensitive to multipath and weather.

questions.query: The MLS AZ antenna is situated...
During periods of super-refraction, radar pulses are...

options.text: attracted by the earth's surface thereby reducing their maximum range.
absorbed by the presence of moisture in the lower part of the atmosphere.
scattered, loosing too much energy for a reliable return.
traveling further causing problems with the timing of the reply pulses.
options.comment:
Correct.

Super refraction causes radio waves to travel further. The longer range may result in timing problems when the reply pulse returns at a  moment the next interrogation pulse is already transmitted.

questions.query: The beam width of a dish antenna is, amongst others, determined by...

options.text: size, nature and aspect ratio of the target.

questions.query: Which statement concerning radar is correct?

options.text: Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR) is a pulse radar.
Airborne weather radar (AWR) is a continuous wave radar.
Distance measuring equipment (DME) is a primary radar.

questions.query: The azimuth resolution of a primary radar installation is improved by...

options.text: the pulse repetion frequency: the higher the PRF, the better the Az resolution.
the RPM of the antenna: the lower the rpm, the better the Az resolution.
the beam width: the smaller the beamwidth, the better the Az resolution.
the pulse length of the transmitted pulses: the smaller the PL, the better the Az resolution.

questions.query: When comparing with ILS, PAR has the advantage of...

options.text: no extra onboard equipment other than a communication radio.

questions.query: A ground radar...

options.comment:
Correct.

The antenna is always on the ground.

options.text: has a smaller range than an airborne radar because of ground reflections.

questions.query: The antenna of the Surface Movement Radar (SMR) rotates at a high rpm in order to...

options.text: refresh the actual position information of relatively fast moving objects.
get a very sharp and detailed image.
compensate for the long pulse and low PRF.
create a small beam with a high azimuth (or bearing) resolution.

questions.query: A primary ground radar...

options.text: interrogates transponders for their squawk code only.

questions.query: An airborne weather radar (AWR) uses interrogation...

options.text: pulse pairs in a random order to allow lock-on on its own replies.
pulses transmitted at a random frequency to detect possible turbulent clouds.
pulses of a constant frequency, amplitude, width and rate.
pulse with a length of 3.2 cm for best reflective properties.
options.comment: The pulse length is not 3.2 cm, but the wavelength is 3.2 cm.

questions.query: A modern weather radar detects windshear by...
The main task of the airborne weather radar is to detect...

options.text: potential turbulent clouds and to aid navigation.
ice, snow and hail with regard to ice protection.

options.comment:
(Dry) ice and snow is normally not detected by an AWR.

The task of the AWR is to detect potential turbulent clouds and aid navigation.

questions.query: A modern airborne weather radar makes use of...

options.text: the Internet for an actual image of the weather en-route.
an Inertial Reference System (IRS) for antenna stabilisation.
a terrain database to position the weather image over a map of the underlying terrain.

questions.query: Which statement regarding airborne weather radars is correct?

options.text: The most effective wave length for strong returns of large rain drops is 9.375 cm.
A stationary antenna has a lateral beam width of about 120-160 degrees.
A flat-plate antenna transmits more side lobes than a parabolic-dish antenna of the same dimension.
The size of the radome limits the size and therefore the effectivity of the antenna.
options.comment:
Correct.

A larger antenna can have a smaller beamwidth.

questions.query: When the gain of a weather radar is reduced...

options.text: the image in the mapping (and weather) mode may improve.

questions.query: SSR makes use of...

options.text: metallic parts in the aircraft construction as a back-up for the PSR.
a ground based transmit/receive antenna and an airborne receive/transmit antenna.
airborne antennas to interrogate the transponders of other aircraft.

questions.query: Mode-S stands for...
Is SSR sensitive to objects in side lobes?

options.text: No, because the interrogator makes use of active targets instead of passive targets.
No, as the rotating flat plate antenna has no side lobes.
Yes, but the range of the side lobes falls below the minimum detectable range.
No, because the interrogator makes use of a side lobe suppression system.

questions.query: A secondary radar requires less transmission power than a primary radar because...

options.text: the pulse repetition frequency, the pulse width and the pulse amplitude are lower.
the interrogation signal only has to travel outbound.

questions.query: The altitude of an aircraft that is supplied by the transponder, is relative to...
The 'reply’ lamp is on when...

options.text: the transponder is replying to a primary radar interrogation.
the transponder is receiving an interrogation signal.

questions.query: An eight-channel GPS receiver selects satellites based on the...
The GPS ‘pseudo range’ is so-called for, because the...
The clock correction signals in the GPS navigation message allow for the correction of the...
The American GPS-NAVSTAR lacks (is missing)...

options.text: accuracy, availability and integrity.
sensitivity, availability and monitoring.
accuracy, measuring range and alerting.
tolerance, functionality and integrity.

questions.query: Where GPS uses WGS-84, does GLONASS use...

options.comment:
This is the Chinese BeiDou reference.

GLONASS uses PZ-90.

questions.query: The advantage of a GNSS receiver over a GPS receiver is...

options.text: a GNSS receiver uses two frequencies to determine the IPD (ionospheric propagation delay).

options.comment: A GPS receiver can also be used worldwide.

options.text: a GNSS receiver has a more effective RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring) function.
a GNSS receiver can be used worldwide.

questions.query: The navigation message of a GPS-satellite contains information about the...
The Russian GNSS system is named...
The navigation message of a GPS satellite...

options.text: takes 12.5 minutes to download the first time.
only gives data regarding that one satellite.

questions.query: The availability of the US GPS-NAVSTAR satellite navigation system is augmented through the use of...

options.text: a satellite based augmentation system such as WAAS or EGNOS.
a connection with on-board inertial navigation systems.

questions.query: RAIM (Receiver Autonomous Integrity Monitoring...

options.text: monitors the satellites via the monitor-stations spread over the earth.
determines differential corrections that can be sent to the users (receivers).
delivers integrity data to the satellite via the up-link stations after the determination of the correct ephemerides by the master control station.
discovers unreliable satellites with a program in the receiver.

questions.query: The American WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System) can be described as...

options.text: the GPS control segment consisting of monitor stations, a master control station and several uplink stations.
a system that provides differential corrections and navigation signals, transmitted by geostatioanry communication satellites.
a differential station in the vicinity of the aerodrome that transmits correction signals for the pseudo ranges.
a pseudo satellite (pseudolite) just in front of the runway to enable CAT 3 operations with GPS.

questions.query:
In GBAS, use can be made of ground-based pseudo satellites (pseudolites) to improve the vertical dilution of precision (VDOP).

These pseudolites...

options.text: have no 'ionospheric propagation delay' in the measured range.
suffer from the 5 degrees elevation mask angle.
transmit their signal via a space-based satellite.

questions.query: Which statement is true regarding differential corrections?

options.text: Within 100 NM WAAS is more accurate than LAAS.
A local area augmentation system requires less reference stations than a wide area augmentation system although the accuracy requirement may be higher.
Differential GPS (DGPS) uses ground based beacons (VOR, DME, ILS) to improve the acuracy durimng the final approach segment.
Every standard (basic) GPS-receiver is suitable to receive DGPS-corrections by connecting a second antenna.

questions.query: The geostationary Inmarsat satellites, will for endorsement of GPS...

options.comment:
Correct.

Integrity data for WAAS and for EGNOS.

options.text: only generate transmissions for the US WAAS; the EU EGNOS uses other SV’s.
perform the function of a pseudolite in polar areas.

questions.query: Receiver autonomous integrity monitoring (RAIM) is applied in GPS...

options.text: near aerodromes in ground stations to improve the geometry.
to reduce the PDOP in order to improve the position accuracy.
and in Inmarsat-satellites to enable them to function as geostationary GPS-navigation transponders
receivers in order to warn the user when a satellite does not transmit proper signals.

questions.query: The US WAAS (Wide Area Augmentation System) makes use of...

options.comment:
RAIM is an algorithm inside the GPS receiver to improve the integrity, not the accuracy.

WAAS uses the Inmarsat satellites to improve the GPS accuracy, integrity and availability.

questions.query: In GBAS, the differential correction signals are applied to correct for...
GBAS uses for its differential correction signals a datalink that operates between...
In PBN, linear lateral performance requirements are expressed in...
How to place Performanc Based Navigation (PBN) in the (future) airspace concept?

options.text: PBN is the pillar of the future airspace concept.
PBN is the foundation of the navigation pillar of the future airspace concept.
PBN is one of the composing parts of the foundation of the navigation pillar of the future airspace concept.

questions.query: Which PBN navigation specification needs specific prior approval?
In RNP 'X' specifications, the number 'X' shows...

options.text: an angular range in which the aircraft should be along a certain distance.
a percentage of the flight time in which the aircraft should fulfil to the required accuracy.
options.comment: The radius of a circle expressed in NM, in which the aircraft should be during 95% of the flight time.

options.text: a range in distance in which the aircraft should be during a certain amount of the flight time.
an angular range in which the aircraft should be during a certain amount of the flight time.

questions.query: The path terminator 'FA' is...

options.text: a path from a fix to an altitude

questions.query: What is the difference between the path terminators TF and CF?

options.text: TF is a time to a fix; CF is a course to a fix.
TF is a time to a fix; CF is a circle to a fix.
TF is a ground path to a fix; CF is an air path to a fix.
TF is a track from one fix to another fix; CF is a course to a fix.

questions.query:
SB193

Where do you use the path definition error (PDE) for?

options.text: Fly parallel off-set tracks.
Manually input it into the navigation system to get back on your original track.
Notify the maintenance department of the PDE the system gives you.
As the PDE is not known by the system, nor by the flight crew, no action can be required.

questions.query: In case of loss of PBN capability...

options.text: the aircraft should land at the nearest suitable airport under guidance of an other aircraft.
the flight may be continued normally, but after the flight a safety report must be filed.
abnormal and contingency procedure are to be used.

questions.query: In PBN, the navigation system error (NSE) is shown as...
In PBN, the navigation system error (NSE) is a combination of...

options.text: the path definition error (PDE) and the flight technical error (FTE).
the path definition error (PDE) and the computing error of the FMS.
the indication error of the EFIS and the reading/interpretation error of the pilot.
the sensor error (GNSS and IRS) and the computing error of the FMS.

questions.query: A Basic RNAV system requires an accuracy of...

The RNAV-10 specification requires at least two independent long-range navigation systems.

What is considered a LRNS?

  1. Oceanic NDB;
  2. airway VOR;
  3. DME-N;
  4. Airborne Weather Radar
  5. GNSS;
  6. INS.
